bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. YODER:H.R. 4654.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted Congressunder Article I of the United States Constitution, including:the power granted Congress under Article I, Section 8, Clause18, of the United States Constitution, and the power grantedto the House of Representatives specifically Clause 3.[Page H4060]

item.name: Energy, Climate and Grid Security Subcommittee
Energy, Climate and Grid Security Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Power.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

summary.text: Lower Electric Bill Act of 2014 - Delays the implementation, administration, or enforcement of the standards for mercury and hazardous air pollutants emitted from new power plants published on February 16, 2012. (The final rule entitled, "National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants From Coal- and Oil-Fired Electric Utility Steam Generating Units and Standards of Performance for Fossil-Fuel-Fired Electric Utility, Industrial-Commercial-Institutional, and Small Industrial-Commercial-Institutional Steam Generating Units" is delayed until the later of five years after enactment of this Act or the date on which the Environmental Protection Agency [EPA] completes a study on the economic impacts on local communities.)

bill.title: Lower Electric Bill Act of 2014

item.title: To delay implementation of the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Power.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
